He has been in this line of work for more than two years and earns about 3,500 PHP each time he sells an animal.

He is applying for his first loan, for 4,000 PHP, to buy baby livestock to raise and sell when they are grown. He plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to supplement his family's income.

She is from the village of General Balao, a part of Solana municipality in Cagayan province on the Luzon islands. Melanie sells Avon products to the local community. She has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month.

In 2009 Melanie joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Melanie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, her second loan from ASKI, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use all additional revenue to expand her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Delegpuntsag

texts.en:
Mr Delegpuntsag is 32 years old, married, and has two children, Barsbayar, 12 and Barsbold, 3, in secondary school and kindergarten respectively. His family used to live in Gobi-Altai aimag (Province) of Mongolia, which is located 1000 kilometers south-west of the capital city of Mongolia. In 2008 they decided to move to Darkhan, the second largest city of Mongolia, in search of a better life. As soon as they moved there, Delegpuntsag bought a small car and started running a taxi business, which has been quite successful, while his wife works as a salesperson in a local grocery store.

Last year they bought a plot of land with a small wooden house on it. Delegpuntsag, an energetic and enthusiastic person, says, “I would like to be financially able to provide a good education and better life for my children." With the loan that he is requesting, he is planning to replace his car by buying a second hand vehicle in better condition.

loans.use: To purchase a second hand car

loans.name: Rose

texts.fr:
Madame ROSE G. est une femme de 82 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants majeurs. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de NGASCOP depuis son inauguration il y a de cela 14 ans. Elle a 28 fois de suite reçu de crédit et a toujours remboursé sans difficulté. 

Elle est éleveuse de porcs. A cause de son âge avancé, elle est aidée par ses enfants pour bien mener cette activité qu'elle pratique depuis plus de 20 ans

Avec son crédit elle va acheter 30 pourceaux à raison de 15.000 francs cfa, et de la nourriture pour leurs alimentation.

Son objectif est de prendre en charge ses besoins personnels, renforcer son épargne et participer à la prise en charge financière de la famille.
texts.en:
Rose G. is an 82 year old woman. She is married and she is the mother of 6 grown children. She has been a member of the Community Bank NGASCOP (Kiva field Partner) since its inception 14 years ago. She has attained 28 past loans and she always repaid the funds without any trouble. She is a pig farmer. Because she is an elderly person she gets help from her children in running the business, one that she has had for more than 20 years. With the help of this loan she will purchase 30 piglets at 15 francs and she will also purchase feed for them. Her goal is to be able to provide for her own needs, to save money, and contribute to the family's finances.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 30 piglets.

loans.name: Lafia Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Lafia sont 3 femmes mariées et 1 veuve qui ont  une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 4 enfants et qui vivent dans des familles polygames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur treizième  prêt. Les prêts passés se sont tous bien dénoués. 
Elles font la vente d’articles divers tels la pomme de terre, les tasses aluminium, les habillements avec  Kadiatou Vieux T..
Avec son nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter, 20 pièces de pagnes et tissus. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Sikasso auprès des grossistes.
Elle vend au marché de KAMALEN SIRAKORO et à domicile, au comptant, en détail et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 35.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et  pouvoir s’acheter des articles pour le trousseau  de mariage de sa première fille.
texts.en:
Of the four members of the Lafia group 3 are married women and one is a widow. The average age is 35 and they have four children each. The live in polygamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, one of the villages of the Sikasso commune (the third administrative region of Mali). They all work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) in order to be able to meet the clients' demands. This is their third loan. The past loans have all been repaid in full. They sell various merchandise items, such as potatoes, aluminium cups, and clothing with Kadiatou Vieux T.. With this loan she will purchase 20 wraps and pieces of fabric. She carries out her purchases from wholesalers in the Sikasso market. She sells her items in the Kamalen Sirakoro market and from her home. She finalizes her sales in cash and often in credit, selling to a clientele made up of both men and women. She plans on seeing monthly earnings of 35.500 francs, a part of which will be put away into savings and part will be used to fill the family's needs. She will also reinvest some earnings back into the business. Her ambitions are to have greater capital funds to be able to meet her clients' demands. She also hopes to purchase wedding items for her eldest daughter’s marriage.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothing.

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr:
Madame Madeleine T., une femme de 43 ans. Elle est mariée et mère 06 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de NGASCOP depuis 14 ans. Elle a 28 fois de suite reçu de crédit et a toujours remboursé dans les délais.

Elle fait de l'embouche porcine. Elle mène cette activité depuis son adhésion dans le Banc Villageois.

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va acheter 25 porcs qu'elle va emboucher et revendre soit sur pied, soit après abattage.

Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge financière de la famille tout en renforçant son niveau d'épargne.
texts.en:
Mrs. Madeleine T. is a 43 year old woman. She is married and she has 6 children. She has been a member of the community bank NGASCOP (Kiva Field Partner) for the past 14 years. She has received 28 past loans and she has always repaid her loan on time. She is a pig farmer. She has been running this business ever since she joined the community bank. With this loan she will purchase 25 piglets for her to raise and later resell. Her goal is to contribute with her husband towards the family's finances and to contribute to their savings.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 25 piglets.

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Oyun R., age 46, lives with her husband and three children in a Ger, traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her oldest daughter attends a university while her youngest son attends a secondary school. Her older son, Ganbaatar, works as a private businessman. Her husband runs a transportation business in his town to supplement his family's income. 

Oyun operates a fruit retail business at a stall in Narantuul, Ulaanbaatar's biggest market. Her business earnings have enabled her to improve her family's quality of living. She is a well organized and skillful businesswoman. She says, "I want to expand my business operation as well as provide a high level, good education to my children". Oyun is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy more fruit to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To buy more fruit.

loans.name: Dil

texts.en: Dil M. is 25 years old and has been selling a fresh fish in the local busy market for more than nine years. She sells fish that she buys from her wholesale supplier and from other fishermen. She is married to Hab Sakin, 23, who works as a furniture producer. The couple has given birth to a young child who is enrolled in the primary school. Presently, Dil M.‘s business has faltered due to insufficient financial capital. In view of that, Dil M. has applied for her first loan, to increase her capital.

loans.use: To increase her capital.

loans.name: Oyundalai

texts.en:
Oyundalai J. is 46 years old and lives with her husband and three daughters in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest two daughters, aged 19 and 18, are university students while her youngest daughter, age 12, attends a local secondary school. 

Oyundalai operates a electron products repair service center, with help of her husband. She began her business next to a grocery shop in 2003. Since then, she has built a stable operation of repairing and performing maintenance on the local people’s electron products. She purchases her raw materials from Erlian, China's border city. Her business is in good spot in the area and she has become popular amongst her customers. They business earnings are the only source of family income. She has used her earnings to pay for her children's tuition fees and on household consumption. Oyundalai is a very modest and hardworking person and is requesting a 3,100,000 MNT loan in order to purchase materials and tools for her repairing center.

loans.use: To purchase materials and tools.

loans.name: Saruul

texts.en:
Saruul T. is 47 years old and lives with her husband and two of her two sons in a Ger, traditional nomadic housing tent, in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. Her oldest son, 20, attends university while her husband and younger son are currently unemployed and stay at home. 

Saruul operates a meat trade business her town, selling various kinds of meat. She began her business in 1998, and has built a stable operation. In the future, she plans to grow her business. Saruul is a friendly and open-minded person and says, "All I want is to provide my children with a good education". She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan so that she can increase her working capital for her meat trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat.

loans.name: Kulziga

texts.en:
Kulziga H., 46 years old, lives with her husband and five children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. Her younger two children, aged 17 and 10, both attend a local secondary school, while her husband works as a guard in a kindergarten. Kulziga sells consumer goods at the local market. She also began a small cafe business in 1994 at Turlik market but still has not built a sustainable operation yet. 

Kulziga purchases her products from the local wholesale stores, and her son helps her business during winter months. The business profits have enabled her to pay her children's tuition fees. Kulziga, a hardworking and honest person, says, " I want to save more money so that I can establish a new and bigger shop and pay my children's university tuition fees." She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan both to purchase more goods at wholesale prices and to help pay for her oldest son's wedding.

loans.use: To purchase more goods at wholesale price

loans.name: Rafat

texts.en:
Rafat S. is dedicated to agricultural work and cattle breeding, which is his family's only income. In his family, he has his wife and 2 children. He has been dedicated to this business for several years and, over time, he has gained experience in cultivating crops. 

Today, Rafat has come to AqroInvest Credit Union with the proposition of obtaining a loan to purchase one baby calf and seeds and fertilizer for planting. It is necessary to point out that in order to carry out the first planting you need to purchase the supplies. It is for this reason that Rafat is confident that his loan request will be successfully granted and he will achieve his objective of having a good harvest to improve his economic situation.

loans.use: To purchase one baby calf and seeds and fertilizer for planting.

loans.name: Lhagva

texts.en:
Lhagva D. lives with her husband and four children in Hentiy province of Mongolia. She and her family all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her two oldest sons, Munhbaatar and Tumurbaatar, both have work in different places, while her younger daughter, Nandintsetseg attends university and the youngest daughter, Tsolmonpurev, studies at a local high school. Her husband is retired and stays at home. 

Lhagva supports the entire family by operating a clothes making business. She repairs, and produces a variety of clothing items for her customers at a small rented workspace. She started her sewing business in 1973 by herself. Since then, she has gained many years of work experience and has built a stable operation. Today she owns 3 different kinds of sewing machines and tools that help her to design and sew the traditional Mongolian clothes. Her daily business income is around 20,000-22,000 MNT. From additional service and clothes repair, her monthly average income is approximately 900,000-1,200,000 MNT. In the future, she hopes to have her own house. 

Lhagva is a very helpful and kind person and says, "I have been sewing traditional clothes for my entire life. Nowadays, I increased my production line and produce clothing and other home items according to my customer's specification. By sewing clothes, I can raise my children well, and so I am very proud of being a seamstress". She is requesting a 1,900,000 MNT  loan in order to purchase fabrics and materials to make school uniforms.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials.

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en:
The livestock business is one that requires much effort for the simple reasons that it requires sun exposure, the physical exertion of moving animals from one place to another, as well as the work it takes to tend to various crops. Nizami S., has dedicated himself, for already ten years, to cattle raising which supports his humble family who so rely on him. His monthly income is about 200-300 AZN. He is married and has four children.

Currently, Nizami has turned to  AqroInvest CUI for a loan of 900 AZN to purchase calves so that he can raise and one milking cow of a specific type: “Damaz”.

loans.use: To purchase one milking cow and one calf.

loans.name: Kamala

texts.en: Kamala H. is 44 years old. She is married and has three children. Since she has lived with her husband, she has worked in the business of buying and selling cattle. She walks through the farms and several settlements to buy cattle at the lowest price to be able to increase her profits. She currently has two cows and two calves. Her monthly income is about 180-220 AZN. Now, Kamala wants to expand her business and, as her children are grown up, she thinks that she will be able to look after more cattle with their help. So she is asking for 1000 AZN in order to purchase cattle and some sheep. Kamala expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her and promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: To purchase cattle and six sheep.

loans.name: Lhagvajav

texts.en:
Lhagvajav H. is 51 years old and lives with her husband and one child in Huvsgul province of Mongolia. Her husband is currently unemployed. Her child is university student. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. She operates a meat trading business in her town, and provides a variety of meats for her customers. 

Lhagvajav started her meat trading business in 2000 at a local market named Baigal - Eej, and has gained much business experience over the years. She is a very open-minded and laborious person. Lhagvajav plans to use her business earnings to improve her family's financial situation and to pay her children's tuition fees. She is requesting a 750,000 MNT loan to buy more meat to expand her working capital.

loans.use: To buy more meat.

loans.name: Ilyas

texts.en:
The business activity from which Ilyas A. makes a living is the breeding of livestock. He started this business 9 years ago with a small number of livestock. As his business has developed, he has acquired greater quantities of animals for their eventual sale and he has gained from their derivatives. 

According to Ilyas, he works very hard so that he can take care of his children and his profit is 350-500 AZN. For that reason, he is always looking for a way to improve his family's living conditions. Currently, he needs a loan of 1000 AZN in order to purchase more cattle to later resell, after breeding them. This will allow him to fully meet the needs of his family.

loans.use: To purchase three cattle.

loans.name: Munhzaya

texts.en:
Munhzaya B. is 36 years old and lives with her two children in the Hentiy province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in a rented yard. Her oldest son attends a university while her younger daughter attends a local high school. 

Munhzaya supports the entire family by operating a clothes making business. She organizes her business very accurately. She has been operating her business since 2000 at a rented workplace. She owns a sewing machine and designs and sews the clothing according to her own tastes. Her daily average income is around 10,000-18,000 MNT and her monthly average income is approximately 400,000-500,000 MNT. She plans to have her own yard in the near future. She likes to sew clothes and it has become her hobby, as well as her profession. Munhzaya is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a fabrics and materials to make various kind of uniforms.

loans.use: To purchase a fabrics, materials.

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Monsieur MOUSSA T. est marié à une femmes et est père de 3 enfants. Il est né à LOULOUNI le 04/07/1978 dans la dite sous préfecture, 3eme région administrative du Mali (SIKASSO).  Il vit à Loulouni dans une famille monogame.
Il fait de la menuiserie métallique avec la confection et réparation (de portes, fenêtres, chaises...) depuis maintenant 8 ans.  Il fait ses prestations avec assez de réussite compte tenu de son expérience à la matière.
Il est à sa première collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso et  compte l’utiliser pour acheter, des matériaux de premières nécessités pour le bon déroulement de ses activités.
Il confectionne les portes, fenêtres...sur commande et ses prestations (réparations) au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Il espère  pouvoir économiser  mensuellement 40.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer la location de l’atelier en plus des apprentis et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne.
texts.en:
Mr. Moussa T. is married and he is the father of 3 children. He was born in Loulouni, Sikasso (third administrative region in Mali) on 4-07-1978. He lives in Loulouni in a monogamous family. He has worked as a joiner for the past 8 years, making and repairing metallic items such as doors, windows, and chairs. His business is quite successful given his experience in the field. This will be the first time he has approached Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) for a loan. He hopes to use it to purchase essential materials for his business. He makes doors and windows, taking orders for new items, and he carries out repairs. His finalizes his transactions in cash only and he caters to a clientele made up of men and women. He hopes to earn 40.000 francs every month and it will be used to pay his store's lease, to hire on more apprentices, and a part will be put away in savings.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase working materials.

loans.name: Rashad

texts.en: Rashad A. has a successful business selling food items. He started his business about 2 years ago, as an additional source of income. His primarily business is livestock breeding. Rashad purchases products, at very low prices, and then resells at a profit. Because he sells in bulk, he deals with a high inventory turnover rate. He has requested a loan of 1000 AZN to increase his business capital. This loan will give him the ability to purchase more products to sell, enabling him to increase his profits and to continue operating a profitable business. Rashad is going to use his loan also to purchase one cow.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell and one cow.

loans.name: Naranjargal

texts.en:
Naranjargal A. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Tuv province of central Mongolia. She lives together with her family in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in her parents' yard. Her daughter, Uranchimeg, studies at high school in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city, while her son, Temuujin, attends a local kindergarten. 

Naranjargal manages a shoe-making business in her town with help of her husband. She graduated Mongolian National University as a teacher. She started her business in 1997 and has built a sustainable operation. Her family's standard of living has improved greatly after operating the shoe-making business. Over the years of successful operation, her business has grown fast and she owns all the tools and equipment which are used in making shoes.

She and her husband work together, and plus she hired one worker. For the future, they plan to expand their business by increasing production capacity and to have their own shoe shop. She says "I work very hard to expand my business and also I teach my shoe-making skills to two handicapped children. In the future, I plan to establish a big shoe-making factory and open my own shop."  

She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of materials used in making traditional shoes.

loans.use: purchasing materials for fabricating shoes

loans.name: Marina

texts.en: Marina M. is a hard-working widow who has one child. For the past two years, Marina has dedicated herself to selling different kinds of home products. She started her business when her husband passed away and she wasn’t able to feed her child. She likes what she sells and has developed a stable business. She makes about 250-300 AZN profit a month, but 30% of that goes to rent. Marina hopes that one day she will be able to build her own shop. Marina is now requesting a loan of 1000 AZN to help purchase new products to sell. This is important for her family's well-being.

loans.use: To purchase new products to sell

loans.name: Sabaly Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Sabaly, 3 femmes mariées et une veuve,  avec une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et 5 enfants  vivent dans des familles  polygames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO, un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur onzième  prêt. Les prêts passés se sont tous bien dénoués. 
Elles font entre autre la vente de charbons de bois, de condiments alimentaires et des chaussures en plastique avec Djata T..
 Avec son nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter  12 douzaines de paires de chaussures en plastique. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Sikasso ville.
Elle vend au marché de KAMALEN SIRAKORO, de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant et  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 35.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne avoir un prêt  plus consistant pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et  devenir grossiste à KAMALEN SIRAKORO
texts.en:
Of the four members of the group named Sabaly 3 are married women and one is a widow. They have an average age of 42 and they have 5 children each, living in polygamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, a village of the Sikasso commune in the third administrative region of Mali. They are members of the microfinance instutution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) with the goal of meeting client demand. This will be their eleventh loan and their past loans have all been successfully repaid. Among other activities they sell wood coal, condiments, and plastic shoes with Djata T.. With this loan she will purchase 12 dozens of plastic shoes. She carries out her purchases in the Sikasso village market. She makes her sales in the market of Kamalen Sirakoro, while travelling, and from her home. She finalizes her sales in cash and often on credit. She sells to a clientele made up of both men and women. She foreseees earning 35.500 francs monthly, of which a part will be put away in savings and a part will be used to fill the family's needs. A part of these earnings will be reinvested back into the business. Her ambitions are to have a source of credit to better satisfy her clientele and to become a wholesaler in Kamalen Sirakoro.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase plastic shoes.

loans.name: Ilqar

texts.en: Ilqar Q. is 42 years old, married, and has two children. His main work consists of breeding cattle. This very profitable activity enables him to provide for the needs of his family. His monthly income is 250-300 AZN. A very ambitious man, Ilqar would like to buy more cattle and build a barn to house them in order to ensure their safety. Due to a lack of finances, Ilqar is asking for a loan of 1000 AZN to purchase more cattle.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Khanish

texts.en:
Khanish K. is 58 years old and the father of three children. His wife is a housekeeper. In order to earn a living, Khanish owns a field for growing watermelon, grapes, and other seasonal fruits and vegetables. His monthly income is about 300-400 AZN.

On his farm, Khanish cannot do any planting because he does not have enough money for seeds and fertilizer. In order to purchase these items, he decided to ask for a loan of 500 AZN. Khanish counts on this planting opportunity to obtain a better yield, which will help him improve the living conditions of his family. He hopes one day to build his own shop next to his house and sell his harvest there.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Mougnoun Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Mougnoun est  constitué de femmes mariées  qui ont  une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et 3 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur cinquième  prêt. Les prêts passés se sont tous bien dénoués. 
Elles font la vente de chaussures, d’huile alimentaire, de vêtements, de Sounbala et de d’atiékè plus du poisson frais  avec  Mariéou S. (qui a l’enfant devant elle sur la photo)   
Avec son nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter, 100kg d’atiékè + 10kg de poissons. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Sikasso ville.
Elle vend au marché de KAMALEN SIRAKORO  et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et  aider son mari à construire leur maison.
texts.en:
The group named Mougnoun is made up of married women with an average age of 37 years and each has 3 children. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, a village in the Sikasso commune int eh thir administrative region of Mali. This group is a member of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). This is their fifth loan and with it they will meet their clients' demands. Their past credits have all been repaid. They sell shoes, cooking oil, clothing, a traditional condiment named Sounbala, and atiéké, a granualted form of casava, as well as fresh fish with Mariéou S. (the individual pictured here with a child). With this new loan she hopes to purchase 100kg of granulated casava root and 10kg of fish. She carries out her purchases in the village market in Sikasso. She makes her sales in the Kamalen Sirakoro markets and from her home, in cash and often on credit. Her clientele is made up of both men and women. She hopes to see monthly earnings of 30.500 francs, a part of which will be put away in savings, a part will be used to fill the family's needs, and a part will be reinvested back in the business. Her ambitions are to have larger capital funds to better satisfy her clients' demands and to help her husband build a house.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase atiéké and frensh fish.

loans.name: Akilimaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe AKILIMAYA est  constitué de six femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 29 ans,  4 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à KABOILA II,  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur quatrième cycle en collaboration avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce  des produits alimentaires en générale  tels que la vente d’atiéké  avec MARIAM D.. 
MARIAM D., qui est un des membres du groupe, compte acheter avec son  prêt 8 sacs d’atiéké.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et souvent en Côte d’Ivoire. Elle revend au  marché de Mancourani I et en famille à une clientèle composée  de femmes et hommes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The group named Akilimaya is made up of six married women with an average age of 29. They each have four children and the majority of the members live in polygamous families in Kaboila II, a district of the village of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. They are on their fourth loan cycle with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). They wish to fill the demands of their clientele. All their past loans have been successfully repaid. This group of women sell general food products, such as atiéké (granulated casava) with Mariam D.. Mariam D. is a member of the group and with her loan she will purcahse 8 sacks of atiéké. She makes her purchaes in the large market in the city of Sikasso, though she goes to Ivory Coast. She resells her merchandise in the Mancourani I market and to her family. Her clientele is made up of both men and money and she finalizes her sales in cash and often on credit. She hopes to earn 40.000 francs every month, of which a part will be put towards the family's expenses and another part will be reinvested back in to the business. Her ambitions are to increase her working capital to better satisfy her clientele.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase atiéké

loans.name: Fadimata

texts.fr:
Fadimata D. est née le 25 Décembre 1977 à Mopti (5ème région administrative du Mali), mariée et mère de 5 enfants, elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou I Extension, un des  quartiers péripheriques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Issue dans une famille de pêcheur, Fadimata D. est née dans cette activité de pêche et de vente de poissons. Elle achète les poissons fumés à Mopti sur commande auprès de ses parents  pour les revendre au grand marché les jours de foire et le marché de leur localité les jours ouvrables où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle (composée essentiellement des des femmes de ménage et vendeuses de condiments alimentaires) pour la qualité de ses poissons.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle a bénéficié d’un premier prêt qui a été correctement remboursé.  
Elle sollicite ce deuxième prêt, pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter, 15 cartons de poissons fumés de différentes qualités.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 125 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Fadimata D. was born December 25, 1977 in Mopti (fifth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She is married and the mother of five children. She lives with her husband and their children in the Sanoubougou I extension, a neighborhood on the outskirts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). Coming from a family of fishermen, Fadimata was born in the business of fishing and selling fish. She buys smoked fish on order in Mopti, from her parents, for resale at the big market on fair days. On regular workdays, she sells the smoked fish at the local market where she is in high demand by her customers (consisting mostly of housewives and condiment vendors) for the quality of her product. In order to better serve a steadily increasing customer base, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution where she received a first loan that was repaid without incident. She is seeking a second loan to expand her business. She plans to buy 15 cartons of smoked fish of varying grades. She expects to achieve a monthly profit of 125,000 FCFA to be used primarily to increase her working capital, help with the family expenses, and pay the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy smoked fish

loans.name: Germaine

texts.fr:
Madame GERMAINE D. est une femme de 52 ans. Elle est veuve et mère de 06 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de NGASCOP depuis 13 ans. Elle a 25 fois reçu de crédit et a toujours remboursé sans difficulté.

Elle fait de l'embouche bovine. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus d'une décennie 

Avec son nouveau crédit il se permettra d'acheter 05 bœufs qu'elle va emboucher pendant au moins 5 mois avant de les revendre au niveau des marchés hebdomadaires de leurs localités.

Son objectif est de subvenir à ses besoins personnels et de prendre en charge les besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Germaine D. is a 52 year old woman. She is a widow and teh mother of 6 children. She has been a member of the community bank NGASCOP (Kiva Field Partner) for the past 13 years. She has had 25 past loans and they have all been repaid without difficulty. She is a cattle farmer, a business she has kept for more than 10 years. With this loan she will purchase 5 calves that she will raise for at least 5 months and then resell them in the weekly market fairs in the region. Her goal is to attend to her personal needs and to provide for the needs of her family.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 5 calves.

loans.name: Fatoumata Yéhia

texts.fr:
Madame  Fatoumata Yéhia Y. est âgée de 46 ans et mère d’une fille. Elle réside avec son époux à Bougoula-Ville Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle s’est initiée aux activités d’achat et de vente de lait en poudre,  de moquettes,  de couvre-lits,  de cache-murs et autres divers articles, depuis plus de dix ans. Elle passe les commandes de ses marchandises à Gao (7ème région administrative du Mali) en provenance d’Algérie dans le Maghreb  qu’elle revend de façon ambulante dans les différentes structures professionnelles de la ville. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée surtout de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Elle vend ses marchandises au comptant et à crédit.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ une année. Elle est à son deuxième prêt qui lui permettra d’acquérir, 13 cartons de laits en poudre, 10 moquettes de différentes dimensions, 4 couvre-lits, 6 paires de cache-murs, 5 carton de Couscous arabe, etc.                                                                                                       Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata Yehia Y. is 46 years old and mother to one daughter. She lives with her husband in the village of Bougoula in Sikasso, third administrative region in the Republic of Mali. For socio-economic reasons she was not able to attend school so she started a business, buying and selling powdered milk, thick wool fabrics, bed spreads, and drapes and various other articles. She has had this business for ten years. She fills her orders for merchandise in Gao (the seventh administrative region in Mali) but the merchandise comes from Maghreb, Algeria. She resells her merchandise door to door and to businesses in her village. Given the high quality of the products she sells she is always sought out by her clientele. She finalizes her sales in cash and on credit. With the goal of better satisfying her ever growing client base she approached the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso last year. This will be her second loan and it will be used to purchase 13 cartons of powdered milk, 10 pieces of wool fabric of different sizes, 4 bed spreads, 6 pairs of curtains, 5 cartons of couscous, etc. She foresees earning a monthly income of 200.000 francs, part of which will used towards the family's expenses, part to pay off the loan, and part will be reinvested into the business.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase various merchandise.

loans.name: Malik

texts.fr:
Monsieur Malik M’BÔ âgé de 37 ans, marié, père de quatre enfants  il habite avec sa famille à Sanoubougou I-Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) .
Il exerce l’activité  d’achat et de vente Prêt à Porter depuis environ quatre ans après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès. 
Vu l’augmentation de sa clientèle et que ses ressources propres ne pouvant satisfaire les attentes de cette clientèle, il  jugea utile de venir auprès de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour lui solliciter ce premier prêt individuel qui lui permettra d’acheter, 10 chemises  de différentes qualités, 15 pantalons de qualités différentes, 20 paires de chaussure  de différentes qualités (Soulier, Ferardine, etc.), 4 complets de veste, 10 Tee-Shirt, etc. 
 Il s’approvisionne à Bamako afin de les revendre dans sa boutique située en pleine cœur de la gare routière de Sikasso à une clientèle composée essentiellement de voyageurs et transporteurs.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce premier crédit un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 120 000 FCFA qui permettra d’augmenter son fonds de commerce mais également d’honorer ses engagements à l’égard de Soro Yiriwaso et couvrir d’autres dépenses familles.
texts.en:
Mr. Malik M’Bô is 37 years old, married and the father of four children. He lives with his family in Sanabougou I, Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). He has been a retailer of ready-to-wear clothing for the past four years, after unsuccessfully trying his hand at different activities. Given the increasing number of customers and his inability to meet their expectations using his own resources, he found it useful to approach the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to request a first personal loan. The loan will enable him to buy clothes of varying quality: 10 shirts, 15 slacks, 20 pairs of shoes (Soulier and Ferardine brands), 4 vests, 10 T-shirts, etc. He resupplies in Bamako and resells his products in his shop located at the very centre of the Sikasso bus station, mainly to a customer base of travellers and drivers. With this first loan he hopes to reach average monthly earnings of 120,000 FCFA. This will enable him to increase his working capital but also honour his commitments to Soro Yiriwaso and cover other family expenses.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing (shirts, slacks, T-shirts, shoes, etc.)

loans.name: Jiguisèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Jiguisèmè (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans, 4 enfants, vivent dans des  familles monogames à Ouayerma II un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur cinquième  prêt, tous les passés se sont bien dénoués. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de friperie, de fruits et légumes et de tasses  avec AWA K..
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter, 4 douzaines de tasses. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville. Les tasses sont vendues au marché de Ouayerma et souvent de façon ambulante dans les familles à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne d’aider son mari à construire leur maison  à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The four women of the Jiguisèmè group are married and, on average, are 33 years old with 4 children. They live in monogamous families in Ouayerma II, one of the neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy their customers’ needs. They are on their fifth loan; all previous loans have been fully repaid. They run various businesses, including selling second-hand clothing and fruits and vegetables. AWA K. sells basins. With her loan, she plans to buy 4 dozen basins. She gets her stock at the large market in Sikasso. The basins are sold at the Ouayerma market and often door-to-door or from the home to a clientele composed of men and women and mostly in cash. They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 CFA of which a part will be used for the family’s needs and the remainder will be invested in the businesses. She hopes to help her husband to build a house in which to live.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basins

loans.name: Soro Yiriwa Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Soro Yiriwa (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Ouayerma II un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur cinquième  prêt. Tous les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués. 
Elles vendent divers  produits  qui sont entre autres des oranges avec MARIAM C..  
Avec son nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter, 3 chargements de charrette  en oranges. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants de SIKASSO et au grand marché de Médine (Sikasso ville). 
Les oranges sont vendues au marché de Ouayerma et à domicile à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
Elle envisage réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne.
Elle ambitionne  avoir son propre magasin au marché afin de mieux  satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The six women of the Soro Yiriwa group are all married and average 38 years of age with an average of four children each. The majority of them live in monogamous families in Ouayerma II, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are working the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to satisfy their customers' needs, and they are on their fifth loan. All the previous loans have been repaid in full. They sell various products, including oranges, which Mariam C. sells. With her new loan, she is planning to buy three barrow loads of oranges. She gets her supplies in Sikasso's neighboring villages and at the large market in Médine (Sikasso town). The oranges are sold at the market in Ouayerma and at home to a customer base made up of men and women, mostly for cash. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 22,500FCFA, of which part will be used for family needs and the rest saved. Her ambition is to have her own shop in the market in order to better satisfy her customers.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruits

loans.name: Tileneya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Tileneya (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans et  3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles monogames à Ouayerma 1 un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Les prêts passés se sont tous bien dénoués. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de fruits et légumes, de poissons, du bois de chauffe, du charbon e bois et des condiments alimentaires avec  KADI B..  
Avec son nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter, 5 paniers de choux, 3 sacs de jakatou, 5 paniers de tomates fraiches, 10 sacs d’oignons et 5 sacs d‘épices. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso  et  dans les localités avoisinantes.  Les produits sont vendus au marché et dans la famille ou sur commande à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
Elle envisage réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000 FCFA dont une partie sera investie dans les activités et l’autre partie en épargne. 
Elle ambitionne d’acheter un terrain à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The four women in the Tileneya group, who are all married, average 28 years of age with three children. They live in monogamous families in Ouayerma 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their fifth loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying their customers' needs. The previous loans have all been repaid in full. They have various activities, which include the sale of fruit and vegetables, fish, firewood, charcoal and wood, and condiments; Kadi B. sells the latter. With her new loan she is planning to buy five baskets of cabbages, three sacks of "jakatou" (a vegetable belonging to the eggplant family), five baskets of fresh tomatoes, ten sacks of onions and five sacks of spices. She gets her supplies at the large market in Sikasso and in neighboring towns. The products are sold at the market and within the family or on order, to a customer base made up essentially of women, and mainly for cash. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 35,000FCFA, of which part will be invested in the business and part saved. Her ambition is to buy a piece of land to live on.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments

loans.name: Jekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Jekafo sont des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles  vivent dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye,  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt en collaboration avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente d‘articles divers tels la friperie  avec Aminata S..
 Avec son nouveau prêt, Aminata S. compte acheter 7 balles de friperie. Elles s’approvisionne à Bamako et au grand marché de Sikasso.
Elles vend à Sikasso ville ( à domicile, dans les marchés et dans les  quartiers de façon ambulante), au comptant, souvent à crédit avec une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 28.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et  pouvoir aménager son point de vente.
texts.en:
The five members of the Jekafo group are married women, who average 39 years of age with an average of three children. They live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their third loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying their customers' needs. The previous loans have been repaid in full. They sell a variety of articles, such as second-hand clothing, sold by Aminata S.. With her new loan, Aminata S. is planning on buying seven bales of second-hand clothes. She gets her supplies in Bamako and at the large market in Sikasso. She sells her goods in Sikasso town (at home, in markets and wandering around the various neighborhoods), for cash, but often on credit to a customer base made up of men and women. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 28,500FCFA, of which part will be used for savings and family needs, while the rest is invested in the business. Her ambition is to have more capital in order to better satisfy her customers and to do up her sales outlet.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothing

loans.name: Believe In God Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Believe In God" Group. They are microentrepreneurs based in Makeni city, in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 1,400,000 leones each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Mariatu K., who is pictured on the left. Mariatu is age 35 and was born in a place called Sanda. She is married with four children. Her husband is a teacher and her children are attending schools:  two in primary school, one in secondary school and the other is still not of school-going age. For ten years now, Mariatu has been selling clothes for babies. She will use her share of this loan to buy more clothes to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy more baby clothes

loans.name: Mohamedi

texts.fr:
Né le 12 Novembre 1988 à Sikasso ville, Monsieur Mohamedi  T. est célibataire sans enfant résidant dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Kaboïla II-Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 N’ayant pas la chance d’avancer aux études, il s’est initié il y a dix ans à cette activité d’achat-vente de fruits et légumes (pomme de terre, orange, melon, patate, citron,etc.). Avec une telle expérience dans ce domaine, il jouit d’une forte réputation et reçoit beaucoup de commandes au niveau de Bamako, mais les ressources nécessaires pour satisfaire ces besoins fait défaut. 
Ainsi, il intégra Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt, qui lui permettra d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour enfin répondre aux attentes de ses clients. 
Ce premier prêt lui permettra d’acheter dans les localités environnantes de Sikasso auprès des producteurs, 10 sacs de pomme de terre, 10 sacs d’orange, 15 sacs de citron, 20 sacs de patate, etc. Ses ventes sont faites en gros et en détail à une clientèle composée de toutes les couches sociales mais surtout de restaurateurs.  
Avec ce premier prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on November 12, 1988 in the town of Sikasso, Mr. Mohamedi T. is single, without children, and lives in a traditional extended family in Kaboila-II-Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). Not having had a chance to progress in his studies, about ten years ago he launched a business purchasing and reselling fruits and vegetables (potatoes, oranges, melons, sweet potatoes, lemons etc). With such a long experience, he enjoys a good reputation in the business and receives many orders in Bamako; however, he lacks the necessary resources to meet his customers’ expectations. This is why he joined Soro Yiriwaso, and is now on his first loan. The loan would allow him to expend his working capital in order to better respond to customer demand. This first loan will allow him to purchase from farmers in the Sikasso region 10 bags of potatoes, 10 bags of oranges, 15 bags of lemons, 20 bags of sweet potatoes etc. He sells wholesale and retail to customers from all social layers, but most of all to restaurant owners. With this first loan, he plans to achieve a monthly income of 100,000 West African Francs, which will be used to cover his essential needs as well as the needs of his family, with the rest reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing fruits and vegetables (potatoes, oranges, lemons, sweet potatoes, etc).

loans.name: Atamu Group

texts.en: Pictured here are members of the Atamu Group. They are microentrepreneurs based in Makeni city, Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 1,000,000 leones each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. The leader of this group is Kadiatu S., pictured on the left. Kadiatu is age 40 and was born in Makeni. She is married with five children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending primary and secondary schools. For many years now, Kadiatu has been selling market food: rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), groundnuts, pepper, etc. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying more stock wholesale to add to her current stock. Also included in the photo is Maseray Kamara, a former group member.

loans.use: To buy rice, palm oil, Maggi, groundnuts, pepper, etc., wholesale

loans.name: Djiguissèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguissèmè sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 48 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Tènè relevant de SAN(quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font  essentiellement de la restauration et l’achat vente de céréales. 
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe sont à leur  4 prêt solidaire.
KADIA T., la présidente du groupe,  compte utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 10 sacs  de céréales (haricot mil, maïs, riz) et une importante quantité d’ingrédients pour la restauration. 
Elle s’approvisionne essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs de céréales et grossistes pour les ingrédients rentrant dans la restauration au marché hebdomadaire de Tènè et effectue sa vente  sur place au marché de Tènè et à domicile, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.000 FCFA qui servira à étoffer son fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
Les autres membres espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 18.000 FCFA chacune.
texts.en:
The members of the Dijugissèmè group are all married women who are on the average 48 years old, with four children. They live in traditional extended families in the village of Tènè (San Prefecture, the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know each other as neighbors and friends; their main line of business is cooking food for sale and selling cereals. After having duly repaid 3 previous loans, they are now on their 4th solidarity loan. Kadia Threa, the group’s leader, plans to use this new loan to purchase ten bags of cereals (beans, millet, corn, and rice) and an ample supply of ingredients for cooking. She purchases her stock locally from cereal farmers as well as, in case of other ingredients, from wholesalers, at the weekly market in Tènè. She sells at the local market of Tènè and out of her home, retail, for cash and on credit, to a customer base composed of both men and women. She anticipates earning an average monthly income of 20,000 West African Francs, which will bolster her business capital and allow her to cover expenses related to food, healthcare, and her children’s schooling. Other members hope to achieve a monthly income of 18,000 West African Francs each.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing food products

loans.name: Fente Allah Bô Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Fente Allah bô sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans, 8 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Tènè relevant de la sous-préfecture de Tènè, préfecture de SAN, (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font essentiellement l’achat vente de tissus, de pagnes wax, de  bijoux et des  produits cosmétiques.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe  sont à leur  5  prêt solidaire.
BINTOU D. utilisera son nouveau prêt pour acheter 2 balles de pagnes wax, 3 douzaines de bijoux et une importante quantité de produits cosmétiques. 
Elle s’approvisionne  essentiellement à Bamako et au Burkina Faso avec les grossistes pour revendre au marché hebdomadaire de Tènè, dans les foires hebdomadaires environnantes et  à domicile, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe comptent avoir 26.000FCFA, BINTOU D. envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 29.000 FCFA qui servira à étoffer son fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses de nourriture, de scolarité et de santé.
texts.en:
The women of the Fente Allah bô group are all married. On average, they are 39 years old, have 8 children and all live in extended traditional families in the village of Tènè in the sub-prefecture of Tènè, prefecture of SAN (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women met each other through neighborhood connections and family ties. They mainly buy and sell fabric, wax “pagnes” (traditional brightly-colored fabric), jewelry and cosmetics. After having repaid in full the 4 previous loans, the women of the group are on their fifth solidarity loan. BINTOU D. will use her new loan to buy 2 bolts of wax “pagnes”, 3 dozen jewelry pieces and a large quantity of cosmetics. She gets her supplies mainly in Bamako and in Burkina Faso from wholesalers. She sells them at the weekly market in Tènè, in weekly market fairs nearby and door-to-door. Cash or credit for retail sales is accepted from a customer base composed of women and men. While the other members of the group expect to earn 26,000 CFA Francs, BINTOU D. envisions making an average monthly profit of 29,000 CFA Francs that she will use to expand her business and provide for food, school and health expenses.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Sabenty Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Sabenty Group. They are microentrepreneurs residing in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of 800,000 leones each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more sales and better profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Zainab K.. Thirty-six-year-old Zainab was born in Makeni. She is married with four children. Her husband is a driver and her children are attending schools:  one in primary school, two in secondary school and the youngest is not of school-going age. Zainab has been selling market food – rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), etc. – for a very long time now. Zainab also sells slippers (flip-flops). With the help of this loan, Zainab will buy market food and slippers in large quantity to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy market food and slippers in large quantity

loans.name: Batoma

texts.fr:
Madame Batoma   Singaré  est âgée de 29 ans,  mariée  et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vit dans la famille paternelle de son mari avec plusieurs autres ménages au quartier Darsalam  près de l’hôpital  Famory Doumbia   de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école en classe de 5ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien), elle débuta très tôt les activités génératrices de revenus, auprès de sa mère qui vendait du poisson fumé et séché.  Nantie  de 5 années d’expérience, elle décide d’évoluer à son propre compte en menant la même activité que sa mère. Batoma vend du poisson séché et fumé et souvent quelques condiments alimentaires tels les oignons au marché Château de Ségou. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation dans son lieu de vente et même dans son quartier. Elle reçoit fréquemment des commandes de Bamako et Kayes où elle a des clients. Ses poissons soigneusement conservés à l’abri de mouches et moustiques
Dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce  et satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus exigeante, elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elle est à son 1er prêt, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 200kg de poissons séchés et 150 kg de poisson fumé. Elle s’approvisionne sur place à Ségou auprès des coopératives de pêcheurs.
Madame Batoma   Singaré  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  de femmes  et d’hommes. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000FCFA, qui servira à prendre en charge certaines dépenses familiales. 
Son ambition est d’avoir une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Batoma Singaré is 29 years old, married and the mother of 4 children. She lives in her husband’s paternal family with several other households in the Darsalam neighborhood near the Famory Doumbia hospital in Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having left school during the 5th year of elementary school (Mali educational system), she went into a revenue-generating business very early with her mother, who sold smoked and dried fish. Provided with 5 years of experience, she decided to take off on her own, running the same business as her mother. Batoma sells dried and smoked fish and often some food condiments such as onions at the Château market in Ségou. She enjoys a great reputation in her sales area and even in her district. She frequently gets orders from Bamako and Kayes where she has clients. Her fish are carefully protected from flies and mosquitos. In the hope of increasing her working capital and satisfy her ever more demanding clientele, she turned to the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. This is her first loan, which she plans to use to buy 200 kilos of dried fish and 150 kilos of smoked fish. She gets her stock on site in Ségou from fishermen's cooperatives. Mrs. Singaré accepts cash and credit and sells to a clientele composed of women and men. She anticipates making a monthly profit of 100,000 CFA, which will be used to provide for certain family expenses.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Too buy fish

loans.name: Haoua

texts.fr:
Madame Haoua Traoré  est âgée de 51 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants dans une famille monogame au quartier Darsalam de  Ségou   (4ème  région du Mali).
N’ayant pas été à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença très tôt les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage à ses côtés, elle bénéficia d’une solide expérience dans le petit commerce. C’est ainsi qu’elle décida  d’évoluer de ses propres ailes dans le créneau du commerce du bois de chauffe et du charbon de bois. Elle mène cette activité depuis 13 ans chez elle-même à domicile. 
Ses ventes sont nombreuses du fait qu’elle est la seule vendeuse de bois de chauffe dans le  quartier. Elle est  sollicitée lors de tous les grands événements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes et  funérailles). 
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, elle fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est en relation depuis 30 mois. Tous les  prêts obtenus : 3 solidaires  et 1 individuel  ont tous été bien remboursés. 
Elle est à son 2ème  prêt individuel qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 2 chargements de camion en bois de chauffe. Elle s’approvisionne à Sanando sur la route de Bamako.
Madame Haoua Traoré vend au comptant  et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100000FCFA  qui lui permettra de finir sa maison et de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille (habillements et nourritures).
texts.en:
Haoua Traore is 51 years old. She is married and the mother of three children. She lives with her husband and their children as a monogamous family in the Darsalam neighborhood in Segou (4th region in Mali). Not having been to school due to social regions, from an early age she started working in income generating activities alongside her mother, who used to sell cooking condiments. After several years of learning at her side she acquired a lot of experience in small business management, so she decided to start her own business in the trade of firewood and charcoal. This is what she has been doing from her own home for the last 13 years. Her sales are good because she is the only firewood seller in the neighborhood. She is especially sought after when there are major social events (weddings, christenings and funerals). In order to keep her increasingly numerous customer base happy, she is seeking the help of Soro Yiriwaso, which which she has been working for 30 months. She has paid back all loans obtained (3 group loans and 1 individual one). This is her second individual loan, which she will use to buy two truckloads of firewood. She stocks up in Sanando, on the Bamako road. Haoua Traore sells for cash or credit to a mostly female customer base. With this loan she hopes to make a monthly profit of 100000FCFA, which will allow her to finish her house and meet the needs of her family (clothing and food).

Translated from French by Alba Sort , Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy firewood

loans.name: God Is Great Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “God Is Great” Group. They are microentrepreneurs in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of 1,400,000 leones each. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit. 

Mariama Siray M. is the leader of this group. Mariama was born in Makeni. She is 38, married to a businessman and they have four children:  one in primary school and three in secondary school. Mariama has been a businesswoman for quite a long time now. She sells baby clothes. She wants this loan in order to buy more baby clothes to add to her business. 

Also included in the photo is the loan officer in charge, handing over the loan.

loans.use: To buy more baby clothes

loans.name: Amidatou

texts.fr:
Madame  Amidatou T. est  une divorcée de 24 ans et mère  de 2 enfants qui  vit chez son père dans une grande famille traditionnelle au  quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Amidatou a abandonné l’école en classe de 9 ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour se marier. Elle a appris la couture auprès de sa mère, après avoir passé plusieurs années d’apprentissage. 
Depuis maintenant 16 ans elle exerce pour elle même. Son atelier, situé au marché de Médine, est facile d’accès ce qui constitue une des raisons de l’affluence de sa clientèle. 
Elle jouit d’une grande réputation et notoriété car ses œuvres : oreillers et habits confectionnés sont très appréciés et prisés à Ségou. 
Dans le dessein de faire face à la demande clientèle de plus en plus grande, elle  fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est à son 1er prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter une nouvelle machine CORNA  sur place à Ségou. 
Madame  Amidatou T. vend ses articles confectionnés (souvent sur commande) au comptant  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permet de gérer son quotidien.  
Son ambition est d’agrandir son atelier, de former beaucoup de personnes.
texts.en:
Mrs. Amidatou T., a 24-year-old divorcee and mother of two children, lives with her father in a large traditional family in the neighborhood of Darsalam, in Ségou (fourth administrative district of the Republic of Mali). Amidatou quit school in 9th grade elementary (under Mali’s education system) to get married. She learned sewing from her mother and spent several years in apprenticeship. She has been working on her own for 16 years. Her workshop at the Médine market is easily accessible, which is one of the reasons for the high customer traffic. She enjoys great reputation and notoriety as her pillows and clothes are in high demand in Ségou. In order to better serve her increasing client base, she turned to the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution. This is her first individual loan, which she intends to use to buy a new CORNA sewing machine in Ségou. Amidatou sells the clothes that she makes (often on order) for cash to a clientele consisting of both men and women. With this loan, she hopes to earn a monthly profit of 100,000FCFA. This will enable her to manage her daily life. Her goal is to expand her workshop and train numerous employees.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a Corna sewing machine

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac is 32 years old and married with two children, ages 1 year and 6 months.  He runs a retail shop in the Mukuru Kwa Njenga slums selling items including soda, sugar, and maize flour.  He has requested a loan of 50,000 KES through Omori Group in Faulu, Kenya.  He will use the loan to buy a weighing machine and a refrigerator. He hopes to start a transport business in the future.

loans.use: To buy a weighing machine and a refrigerator.

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata C. est âgée de 44 ans, mariée  et mère  de 3 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son mari  dans une grande famille traditionnelle au  quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Fatoumata a abandonné l’école en classe de 8ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour faire le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des habits et ustensiles de cuisine. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage, à son mariage, elle commence à évoluer seule pour mener le même commerce que sa mère. 
Elle mène son activité depuis 26 ans et jouit d’une grande réputation et notoriété. Sa force de vente est due à la qualité de ses articles. 
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfice, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 5 ans, après 8 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels,  tous correctement remboursés. 
Elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 1 balle de pagnes wax et 50 baignoires en plastiques et aluminium . Elle s’approvisionne au Burkina Faso.
Madame Fatoumata C. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30.000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permet de participer aux événements sociaux.  
Son ambition est de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata C. is 44 years old, married and the mother of 3 children. She lives with her husband in a traditional extended family in the Darsalam district in Segou (the 4th administrative district of Mali). Fatoumata has left school after the 8th grade (Mali’s educational system) in order to join her mother in the business of selling clothing and kitchen utensils. After several years of apprenticeship, once she got married, she launched her own business in the same line as her mother. She has been in business for 26 years and is well-known and respected. Her strength is in high quality of her products. In order to bolster her business capital and increase her income, she has turned to Soroo Yiriwaso. She has been collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso for five years and had 8 solidarity loans and two individual loans, all properly repaid. She is now on her 3rd individual loan which she plans to sue to purchase 1 bale of wax “pagnes” [traditional colorful fabric] and 50 plastic and aluminum bathtubs. She stocks up in Burkina Faso. Mrs. Fatoumata C. sells for cash and on credit to a customer base composed of both women and men. With this loan, she anticipates achieving a monthly benefit of 30,000 West African francs. This income will allow her to take part in community events. Her goal is to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothing and kitchen utensils

loans.name: Tabaksneh Group

texts.en:
These are microentrepreneurs from Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, seeking a loan of 1,500,000 leones each to enable them to expand their businesses. With their loan, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses and make more sales and profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living, send their children to school and feed and clothe them. 

Mohamed D. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group. Mohamed was born in one of the villages that make up Sanda, near Makeni. This 41-year-old is married and has three children:  two in secondary school and one in primary school. Mohamed sells slippers and has been managing this business for countless years. With his share of the loan, he will buy dozens of slippers to add to his current stock. 

Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.

loans.use: To buy dozens of slippers

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon is 40 years old and married with two children who attend school.  For two years, he has been operating a boda-boda (motorbike) transport business where he has employed one person.  He also grows vegetables to earn more income.  He was previously selling building materials for a living.  He appreciates Faulu Kenya for previously supporting him with capital for his business. He has requested a loan of 50,000 KES to buy another motorbike.  He hopes to own a fleet of motorbikes in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en: Edward is a 36-year-old member of Future Target Group in Faulu Kenya.  He is married and blessed with two children ages 7 and 11.  He has been selling secondhand shoes to earn his daily bread.  He was previously running a retail shop.  He has been in the business for nine years and has employed one person.  His business is located in the Gikomba open air market.  The fact that he is a member of Faulu Kenya and has previously received two loans has improved his financial status.  He has now requested a loan of 45,000 KES to buy more shoes for selling.  In five years, he hopes to be selling shoes wholesale.

loans.use: To stock more shoes for his shop.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a 36-year-old husband and father of a seven-year-old child.  For twelve years, he has been selling sugarcane.  He also runs a boda-boda (motorbike) transport business.  He employs three people and hopes to hire two more in the future.  He has learned good customer service skills from Faulu Kenya, where he has previously taken out a loan.  He is requesting another loan for 40,000 KES to buy more sugarcane for selling.  In five years, he hopes to have two other locations for his business.

loans.use: To buy sugarcane for selling.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy is 27 years old and a member of the Favour self-help group in Faulu Kenya.  She does embroidery and sells clothes to earn a living.  She also gets financial support from her husband.  Nancy has been in business for two years thanks to Faulu Kenya for assisting her when she needed to rent a business premise.  She has requested for a loan of 40,000 KES to  purchase more clothing for selling.  She hopes to provide a good education to her three children.  She also hopes to expand her business into wholesale.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing stock.

loans.name: Benter

texts.en: Benter is a 28-year-old wife and mother to three children who are in school.  For two years, she has been involved in a tailoring business.  Apart from that, she runs a cafeteria to boost her income.  She also gets financial support from her husband.  She has seen her business expand since she became part of Faulu Kenya as part of the New Jerusalem group.  She now requests a 40,000 KES loan to buy an overlock sewing machine, fabric, and other sewing tools.  She hopes to grow her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: To buy an overlock sewing machine, fabric, and tools.

loans.name: Dzyunik

texts.en: Dzyunik A. lives in Tskhuk village in the Syunik region of Armenia. Dzyunik and her husband are farmers. To increase her family income and prepare for the upcoming winter, Dzyunik has applied for a loan to fund the purchase of some cattle and feed for them.

loans.use: To buy cattle and feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more used clothing for selling.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is 51 years old, married, and blessed with five children aged 29, 27, 24, 20 and 18.  Two of the children are still in school.  He is an entrepreneur who runs a butcher shop, and also does some farming to boost his income.  He used to run a cafeteria.  Stephen runs his business in the Mukuru Kayaba slums and has employed one person.  As a member of Faulu Kenya – in Eagles group – he is requesting a loan of 25, 000 KES to buy a refrigerator, glass display, and meat.  He hopes to excel in his business and buy his own house in the future.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator, glass display

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.
